statement.p: Suppose that f(x) is a function and F(x) = e^{(x^2-3)} + 1 is an antiderivative of f(x). Evaluate the definite integral \displaystyle\int_1^{\sqrt5} f(x)\,\dee{x}.

solution.p:
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2 (Theorem ) tells us that
\int_1^{\sqrt5} f(x)\,\dee{x} &= F(\sqrt5) - F(1)
&= \big( e^{(\sqrt5^2-3)} + 1 \big) - \big( e^{(1^2-3)} + 1 \big)
&= e^{5-3} - e^{1-3} = e^2-e^{-2}

statement.p: For the function f(x) = x^3 -\sin 2x, find its antiderivative F(x) that satisfies F(0)=1.

hint.p: First find the general antiderivative by guessing and checking.

solution.p:
First, let's find a general antiderivative of x^3-\sin(2x).
One function with derivative x^3 is \dfrac{x^4}{4}.
To find an antiderivative of \sin(2x), we might first guess \cos(2x); checking, we see \diff{}{x}\{\cos(2x)\}=-2\sin(2x). So, we only need to multiply by -\dfrac{1}{2}: \displaystyle\diff{}{x}\left\{-\dfrac{1}{2}\cos 2x\right\}=\sin(2x).
So, the general antiderivative of f(x) is \dfrac{x^4}{4}+\dfrac{1}{2}\cos 2x+C. To satisfy F(0)=1, we need The symbol \iff is read if and only if. This is used in mathematics to express the logical equivalence of two statements. To be more precise, the statement P \iff Q tells us that P is true whenever Q is true and Q is true whenever P is true.

\Big[\frac{x^4}{4}+\frac{1}{2}\cos 2x+C\Big]_{x=0}=1 \iff \frac{1}{2} + C = 1 \iff C=\frac{1}{2}
So F(x) = \dfrac{x^4}{4}+\dfrac{1}{2}\cos 2x+\dfrac{1}{2}.

statement.p: Decide whether each of the following statements is true or false. Provide a brief justification.

ol.label: a
ol.li: If f(x) is continuous on [1, \pi] and differentiable on (1,\pi), then \displaystyle\int_1^\pi f'(x)\,\dee{x} = f(\pi)-f(1).
If f is continuous on [a, b] then \displaystyle\int_a^b xf(x)\,\dee{x} = x\int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x} .

hint.p: Be careful. Two of these make no sense at all.

solution.p: (a) This is true, by part 2 of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Thereom , with G(x)=f(x) and f(x) replaced by f'(x).

(b) This is not only false, but it makes no sense at all. The integrand is strictly positive so the integral has to be strictly positive. In fact it's +\infty. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus does not apply because the integrand has an infinite discontinuity at x=0.
(c) This is not only false, but it makes no sense at all, unless \int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x}=\int_a^b xf(x)\,\dee{x} = 0. The left hand side is a number. The right hand side is a number times x.
For example, if a=0, b=1 and f(x) = 1, then the left hand side is \int_0^1 x\,\dee{x} = \frac{1}{2} and the right hand side is x\int_0^1 \dee{x}=x.

statement.p: True or false: an antiderivative of \dfrac{1}{x^2} is \log (x^2) (where by \log x we mean logarithm base e).

hint.p: Check by differentiating.

solution.p:
This is a tempting thought:
\int \frac{1}{x}\dee{x}&=\log|x|+C
so perhaps similarly \int \frac{1}{x^2}\dee{x}&\stackrel{?}{=}\log|x^2|+C=\log(x^2)+C
We check by differentiating: \diff{}{x}\{\log(x^2)\} &= \diff{}{x}\{2\log x\}=\frac{2}{x} \neq \frac{1}{x^2}
So, it wasn't so easy: false.
When we're guessing antiderivatives, we often need to adjust our original guesses a little. Changing constants works well; changing functions usually does not.

statement.p: True or false: an antiderivative of \cos(e^x) is \frac{\sin(e^x)}{e^x}.

hint.p: Check by differentiating.

solution.p:
This is tempting:
\diff{}{x}\{\sin(e^x)\} &= e^x\cos(e^x)
so perhaps \diff{}{x}\left\{\frac{\sin(e^x)}{e^x}\right\} &\stackrel{?}{=} \cos(e^x)
We check by differentiating: \diff{}{x}\left\{\frac{\sin(e^x)}{e^x}\right\} &=\frac{e^x\left(\cos(e^x)\cdot e^x\right)-\sin(e^x)e^x}{e^{2x}} &\mbox{(quotient rule)}
& = \cos (e^x) - \frac{\sin(e^x)}{e^x}
&\neq \cos(e^x)
So, the statement is false.
When we're guessing antiderivatives, we often need to adjust our original guesses a little. Dividing by constants works well; dividing by functions usually does not.

statement.p: Suppose F(x) = \displaystyle\int_7^x \sin(t^2)\dee{t}. What is the instantaneous rate of change of F(x) with respect to x?

hint.p: Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1.

solution.p: The instantaneous rate of change of F(x) with respect to x is another way of saying F'(x). From the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, we know this is \sin (x^2).

statement.p: Suppose F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{2}^x e^{1/t}\dee{t}. What is the slope of the tangent line to y=F(x) when x=3?

hint.p: Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1.

solution.p: The slope of the tangent line to y=F(x) when x=3 is exactly F'(3). By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, F'(x) = e^{1/x}. Then F'(3) = e^{1/3} = \sqrt[3]{e}.

statement.p: Suppose F'(x)=f(x). Give two different antiderivatives of f(x).

hint.p: You already know that F(x) is an antiderivative of f(x).

answer.p: For any constant C, F(x)+C is an antiderivative of f(x). So, for example, F(x) and F(x)+1 are both antiderivatives of f(x).

solution.p: For any constant C, F(x)+C is an antiderivative of f(x), because \diff{}{x}\{F(x)+C\} = \diff{}{x}\{F(x)\} = f(x). So, for example, F(x) and F(x)+1 are both antiderivatives of f(x).

statement.p:
In Question, Section, we found that
\int_0^a\sqrt{1-x^2}\dee{x}=\frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{1}{2}\arccos(a)+\frac{1}{2}a\sqrt{1-a^2}.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Find a function F(x) that satisfies F'(x) = \sqrt{1-x^2} and F(0)=\pi.

hint.p: (a) Recall \diff{}{x}\{\arccos x\} = \frac{-1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}.
(b) All antiderivatives of \sqrt{1-x^2} differ from one another by a constant. You already know one antiderivative.

ol.label: a
a

li.p: Let G(x) = \frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2}\arccos(x)+\frac{1}{2}x\sqrt{1-x^2}. We showed in part (a) that G(x) is an antiderivative of \sqrt{1-x^2}. Since F(x) is also an antiderivative of \sqrt{1-x^2}, F(x) = G(x)+C for some constant C (this is Lemma).

Note G(0)=\displaystyle\int_0^0\sqrt{1-x^2}\dee{x} =0, so if F(0)=\pi, then F(x)=G(x)+\pi. That is,
F(x) = \frac{5\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2}\arccos(x)+\frac{1}{2}x\sqrt{1-x^2}\ .

statement.p:
Evaluate the following integrals using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2, or explain why it does not apply.
\displaystyle\int_{-\pi}^\pi \cos x \dee{x}.
\displaystyle\int_{-\pi}^\pi \sec^2 x \dee{x}.
\displaystyle\int_{-2}^0 \frac{1}{x+1}\dee{x}.

hint.p: In order to apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2, the integrand must be continuous over the interval of integration.

answer.p: (b),(c) The FTC does not apply, because the integrand is not continuous over the interval of integration.

ol.label: a
ol.li: The antiderivative of \cos x is \sin x, and \cos x is continuous everywhere, so \displaystyle\int_{-\pi}^\pi \cos x \dee{x} = \sin(\pi)-\sin(-\pi) = 0.
Since \sec^2 x is discontinuous at x=\pm\frac{\pi}{2}, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2 does not apply to \displaystyle\int_{-\pi}^\pi \sec^2 x \dee{x}.
Since \frac{1}{x+1} is discontinuous at x=-1, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2 does not apply to \displaystyle\int_{-2}^0 \frac{1}{x+1}\dee{x}.

introduction.p: Questions through are meant to help reinforce key ideas in the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and its proof.

statement.p: As in the proof of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, let F(x) = \int_{a}^x f(t)\dee{t}. In the diagram below, shade the area corresponding to F(x+h)-F(x).

hint.p: Use the definition of F(x) as an area.

solution.p: Using the definition of F, \textcolor{red}{F(x)} is the area under the curve from a to x, and \textcolor{blue}{F(x+h)} is the area under the curve from a to x+h. These are shown on the same diagram, below.
Then the area represented by \textcolor{blue}{F(x+h)}-\textcolor{red}{F(x)} is the area that is outside the red, but inside the blue. Equivalently, it is \int\limits_{x}^{x+h} f(t)\dee{t}.

statement.p:
Let F(x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)\dee{t}, where f(t) is shown in the graph below, and 0 \leq x \leq 4.
Is F(0) positive, negative, or zero?
Where is F(x) increasing and where is it decreasing?

hint.p: F(x) represents net signed area.

answer.p: (b) increasing when 0 \lt x \lt 1 and 3 \lt x \lt 4; decreasing when 1 \lt x \lt 3

solution.p: We evaluate F(0) using the definition: F(0) = \int_0^0 f(t)\dee{t}=0. Although f(0) \gt 0, the area from t=0 to t=0 is zero.

As x moves along, F(x) adds bits of signed area. If it's adding positive area, it's increasing, and if it's adding negative area, it's decreasing. So, F(x) is increasing when 0 \lt x \lt 1 and 3 \lt x \lt 4, and F(x) is decreasing when 1 \lt x \lt 3.

statement.p:
Let G(x) = \displaystyle\int_x^0 f(t)\dee{t}, where f(t) is shown in the graph below, and 0 \leq x \leq 4.
Is G(0) positive, negative, or zero?
Where is G(x) increasing and where is it decreasing?

hint.p: Note G(x)=-F(x), when F(x) is defined as in Question.

answer.p: (b) G(x) is increasing when 1 \lt x \lt 3, and it is decreasing when 0 \lt x \lt 1 and when 3 \lt x \lt 4.

solution.p:
This question is nearly identical to Question, with
G(x) = \displaystyle\int_x^0 f(t)\dee{t} = -\displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)\dee{t}=-F(x).
So, G(x) increases when F(x) decreases, and vice-versa. Therefore: G(0)=0, G(x) is increasing when 1 \lt x \lt 3, and G(x) is decreasing when 0 \lt x \lt 1 and when 3 \lt x \lt 4.

statement.p: Let F(x) = \displaystyle\int_a^x t\dee{t}. Using the definition of the derivative, find F'(x).

hint.p: Using the definition of the derivative, F'(x) = \displaystyle\lim_{h \to 0}\dfrac{F(x+h)-F(x)}{h}.
The area of a trapezoid with base b and heights h_1 and h_2 is \frac{1}{2}b(h_1+h_2).

solution.p: So, F'(x)=x.

statement.p: Give a continuous function f(x) so that F(x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)\dee{t} is a constant.

hint.p: There is only one!

solution.p: If F(x) is constant, then F'(x)=0. By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, F'(x)=f(x). So, the only possible continuous function fitting the question is f(x)=0.
This makes intuitive sense: if moving x doesn't add or subtract area under the curve, then there must not be any area under the curve--the curve should be the same as the x-axis.

As an aside, we mention that there are other, non-continuous functions f(t) such that \int_0^x f(t)\dee{t} = 0 for all x. For example, f(t) = \left\{\begin{array}{cc} 0 & x \neq 0\\ 1 & x=0 \end{array}\right.. These kinds of removable discontinuities will not factor heavily in our discussion of integrals.

introduction.p: So far, we have been able to guess many antiderivatives. Often, however, antiderivatives are very difficult to guess. In Questions through , we will find some antiderivatives that might appear in a table of integrals. Coming up with the antiderivative might be quite difficult (strategies to do just that will form a large part of this semester), but verifying that your antiderivative is correct is as simple as differentiating.

statement.p: Evaluate and simplify \diff{}{x}\{x\log(ax)-x\}, where a is some constant and \log(x) is the logarithm base e. What antiderivative does this tell you?

hint.p: If \diff{}{x}\{F(x)\}=f(x), that tells us \int f(x)\dee{x} = F(x)+C.

answer.p: \int \log(ax)\dee{x}= x\log(ax)-x+C, where a is a given constant, and C is any constant.

solution.p:
\diff{}{x}\{x\log(ax)-x\}&=x\left(\frac{a}{ax}\right)+\log(ax)-1\quad\mbox{(product rule, chain rule)}
&=\log(ax)
So, we know \int \log(ax)\dee{x}&= x\log(ax)-x+C
where a is a given constant, and C is any constant.
Remark: \int \log(ax)\dee{x} can be calculated using the method of Integration by Parts, which you will learn in Section.

statement.p: Evaluate and simplify \diff{}{x}\{e^x\left(x^3-3x^2+6x-6\right)\}. What antiderivative does this tell you?

hint.p: When you're differentiating, you can leave the e^x factored out.

solution.p: Remark: \int x^3e^x\dee{x} can be calculated using the method of Integration by Parts, which you will learn in Section.

statement.p: Evaluate and simplify \diff{}{x}\left\{\log\left|x+\sqrt{x^2+a^2}\right|\right\}, where a is some constant. What antiderivative does this tell you?

hint.p: After differentiation, you can simplify pretty far. Keep at it!

answer.p: \displaystyle\int \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x^2+a^2}}\dee{x} = \log\left|x+\sqrt{x^2+a^2}\right|+C when a is a given constant. As usual, C is an arbitrary constant.

solution.p: Remark: \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2+a^2}}\dee{x} can be calculated using the method of Trigonometric Substitution, which you will learn in Section.

statement.p: Evaluate and simplify \displaystyle\diff{}{x}\left\{\sqrt{x(a+x)}-a\log\left(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{a+x}\right)\right\}, where a is some constant. What antiderivative does this tell you?

hint.p: This derivative also simplifies considerably. You might need to add fractions by finding a common denominator.

solution.p: Remark: \int \frac{x}{\sqrt{x(a+x)}}\dee{x} can be calculated using the method of Trigonometric Substitution, which you will learn in Section.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\int_0^2 \big(x^3+\sin x)\,\dee{x}.

hint.p: Guess a function whose derivative is the integrand, then use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2.

solution.p:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,
\int_0^2 \big(x^3+\sin x)\,\dee{x} &=\left[\frac{x^4}{4}-\cos x\right]_0^2
&=\left(\frac{2^4}{4}-\cos 2\right)-\left(0 -\cos 0\right)
&= 4-\cos2+1=5-\cos2.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\int_1^2 \frac{x^2+2}{x^2}\,\dee{x}.

hint.p: Split the given integral up into two integrals.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\int \dfrac{1}{1+25x^2}\dee{x}.

hint.p: The integrand is similar to \dfrac{1}{1+x^2}, so something with arctangent seems in order.

solution.p:
The integrand is similar to \dfrac{1}{1+x^2}, which is the derivative of arctangent. Indeed, we have
\displaystyle\int \dfrac{1}{1+25x^2}\dee{x} &= \int \dfrac{1}{1+(5x)^2}\dee{x}.
So, a reasonable first guess for the antiderivative might be \textcolor{red}{F(x)} &\textcolor{red}{\stackrel{?}{=} \arctan(5x)}.
However, because of the chain rule, \color{red}{F'(x)} &\color{red}{= \dfrac{5}{1+(5x)^2}}.
In order to fix the numerator, we make a second guess: \color{blue}{F(x)} &\color{blue}{= \frac{1}{5}\arctan(5x)}
\color{blue}{F'(x)} &\color{blue}{= \dfrac{1}{5}\left(\dfrac{5}{1+(5x)^2}\right) = \dfrac{1}{1+25x^2}}
\mbox{So,}\qquad \displaystyle\int \dfrac{1}{1+25x^2}\dee{x}&=\frac{1}{5}\arctan(5x)+C.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\int \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2-x^2}}\dee{x}.

hint.p: The integrand is similar to \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}, so factoring out \sqrt{2} from the denominator will make it look like some flavour of arcsine.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\int \tan^2 x \dee{x}.

hint.p: We know how to antidifferentiate \sec^2 x, and there is an identity linking \sec^2 x with \tan^2 x.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\int 3 \sin x \cos x \dee{x}.

hint.p: Recall 2\sin x \cos x = \sin(2x).

solution.p:
Solution 1: This might not obviously look like the derivative of anything familiar, but it does look like half of a familiar trig identity: 2\sin x \cos x = \sin(2x).
\int 3 \sin x \cos x \dee{x}&=\int \frac{3}{2}\cdot 2\sin x \cos x \dee{x}
&=\int \frac{3}{2} \sin(2x)\dee{x}
So, we might guess that the antiderivative is something like -\cos(2x). We only need to figure out the constants. \diff{}{x}\{-\cos(2x)\}&=2\sin(2x)
\mbox{So,}\qquad \diff{}{x}\left\{-\frac{3}{4}\cos(2x)\right\}&=\frac{3}{2}\sin(2x)
\mbox{Therefore,}\qquad \int 3\sin x \cos x\dee{x}&=-\frac{3}{4}\cos(2x)+C
Solution 2: You might notice that the integrand looks like it came from the chain rule, since \cos x is the derivative of \sin x. Using this observation, we can work out the antideriative:
\diff{}{x}\left\{\sin^2 x\right\}&=2\sin x \cos x
\diff{}{x}\left\{\frac{3}{2}\sin^2 x\right\}&=3\sin x \cos x
\mbox{So,}\qquad \int 3\sin x \cos x \dee{x}&=\frac{3}{2}\sin^2 x+C
These two answers look different. Using the identity \cos(2x)=1 - 2 \sin^2(x), we reconcile them:
-\frac{3}{4}\cos(2x)+C&= -\frac{3}{4}\left(1-2\sin^2x\right)+C
&=\frac{3}{2}\sin^2 x + \left(C-\frac{3}{4}\right)
The \frac{3}{4} here is not significant. Remember that C is used to designate a constant that can take any value between -\infty and +\infty. So C-\frac{3}{4} is also just a constant that can take any value between -\infty and +\infty. As the two answers we found differ by a constant, they are equivalent.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\int \cos^2 x \dee{x}.

solution.p:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1,
F'(x)&=\diff{}{x} \int_0^x \log(2+\sin t)\,\dee{t} &&=\log(2+\sin x)
G'(y)&=\diff{}{y}\bigg[- \int_0^y \log(2+\sin t)\,\dee{t}\bigg] &&=-\log(2+\sin y)
So,
F'\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big)=\log 3\qquad G'\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big)=-\log(3)

statement.p: Let f(x)=\displaystyle\int_1^x 100(t^2-3t+2)e^{-t^2}\dee{t}. Find the interval(s) on which f is increasing.

hint.p: There is a good way to test where a function is increasing, decreasing, or constant, that also has something to do with topic of this section.

answer.p: f(x) is increasing when -\infty \lt x \lt 1 and when 2 \lt x \lt \infty.

solution.p: Remark: even without the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, since f(x) is the area under a curve from 1 to x, f(x) is increasing when the curve is above the x-axis (because we're adding positive area), and it's decreasing when the curve is below the x-axis (because we're adding negative area).

statement.p: If F(x)={\displaystyle\int_0^{\cos x} \frac{1}{t^3+6}\,\dee{t}}, find F'(x).

hint.p: See Example .

solution.p:
Write G(x)={\displaystyle\int_0^x \frac{1}{t^3+6}\,\dee{t}}. By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, G'(x)=\dfrac{1}{x^3+6}. Since F(x)=G(\cos x), the chain rule gives us
F'(x)=G'(\cos x)\cdot(-\sin x)=-\frac{\sin x}{\cos^3x+6}

statement.p: Compute f'(x) where f(x)= \displaystyle\int_0^{1+x^4}e^{t^2}\dee{t}.

hint.p: See Example .

solution.p:
Define g(x)= \displaystyle\int_0^x e^{t^2}\dee{t}. By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, g'(x)=e^{x^2}. As f(x)=g(1+x^4) the chain rule gives us
f'(x)=4x^3g'(1+x^4)=4x^3e^{(1+x^4)^2}

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle\diff{}{x}\left\{\int_0^{\sin x}(t^6+8)\dee{t}\right\}.

hint.p: See Example .

solution.p:
Define g(x)=\int_0^x (t^6+8)\dee{t}. By the fundamental theorem of calculus, g'(x)=x^6+8. We are to compute the derivative of f(x)=g(\sin x). The chain rule gives
\diff{}{x}\left\{\int_0^{\sin x}(t^6+8)\dee{t}\right\} =g'(\sin x)\cdot \cos x=\big(\sin^6 x+8\big)\cos x

statement.p: Let F(x)= \displaystyle\int_0^{x^3}e^{-t}\sin\left(\frac{\pi t}{2}\right)\,\dee{t}. Calculate F'(1).

hint.p: See Example .

solution.p: Let G(x)= \displaystyle\int_0^{x}e^{-t}\sin\left(\frac{\pi t}{2}\right)\,\dee{t}. By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, G'(x)=e^{-x}\sin\big(\frac{\pi x}{2}\big) and, since F(x)=G(x^3), F'(x)=3x^2G'(x^3)=3x^2e^{-x^3}\sin\big(\frac{\pi x^3}{2}\big). Then F'(1)=3e^{-1}\sin\big(\frac{\pi }{2}\big) =3e^{-1}.

statement.p: Find \displaystyle \diff{}{u} \left\{ \int_{\cos u}^0 \frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^3} \right\}.

hint.p: See Example .

solution.p:
Define \displaystyle G(x) = \int_x^0 \frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^3} = - \int_0^x \frac1{1+t^3}\,\dee{t}, so that \displaystyle G'(x) = - \frac1{1+x^3} by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1. Then by the chain rule,
\diff{}{u} \left\{ \int_{\cos u}^0 \frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^3} \right\} &= \diff{}{u} G(\cos u) = G'(\cos u) \cdot \diff{}{u}\cos u
&= {-}\frac{1}{1+\cos^3 u} \cdot (-\sin{u}).

statement.p: Find f(x) if x^2=1+\displaystyle\int_1^x f(t)\dee{t}.

hint.p: Apply \diff{}{x} to both sides.

solution.p: Applying \diff{}{x} to both sides of x^2=1+\int_1^x f(t)\dee{t} gives, by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, 2x=f(x).

statement.p: If x \sin(\pi x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)\, \dee{t} where f is a continuous function, find f(4).

hint.p: What is the title of this section?

statement.p:
Consider the function \displaystyle F(x)=\int_0^{x^2} e^{-t}\,\dee{t} +\int_{-x}^0 e^{-t^2}\,\dee{t}.
Find F'(x).
Find the value of x for which F(x) takes its minimum value.

hint.p: See Example .

solution.p: (b) Observe that F'(x) \lt 0 for x \lt -1/2 and F'(x) \gt 0 for x \gt -1/2. Hence F(x) is decreasing for x \lt -1/2 and increasing for x \gt -1/2, and F(x) must take its minimum value when x=-1/2.

statement.p: If F(x) is defined by \displaystyle F(x) = \int_{x^4-x^3}^x e^{\sin t}\,\dee{t}, find F'(x).

hint.p: See Example .

solution.p:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1,
G'(y)=e^{\sin y}\qquad
Hence, by the chain rule,
F'(x) &= G'(x)- G'(x^4-x^3)\ \diff{}{x}\big\{x^4-x^3\big\}
&= G'(x)- G'(x^4-x^3)\ (4x^3-3x^2)
&=e^{\sin x}-e^{\sin(x^4-x^3)}\big(4x^3-3x^2\big)

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \diff{}{x}\bigg\{\int_{x^5}^{-x^2} \cos\big(e^t\big)\,\dee{t} \bigg\}.

hint.p: See Example .

statement.p: Differentiate \displaystyle \int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\sin t}\,\dee{t} for 0\lt x\lt \log \pi.

hint.p: See Example .

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \int_1^5 f(x)\,\dee{x}, where \displaystyle f(x)= \begin{cases} 3 &\text{ if $x\le 3$} \\ x &\text{ if $x\ge 3$} \end{cases}.

hint.p: Split up the domain of integration.

statement.p: If f'(1)=2 and f'(2)=3, find \displaystyle\int_1^2 f'(x) f''(x)\,\dee{x}.

hint.p: It is possible to guess an antiderivative for f'(x) f''(x) that is expressed in terms of f'(x).

solution.p: Remark: evaluating antiderivatives of this type will occupy the next section, Section.

statement.p: A car traveling at 30\,\textrm{m}/\textrm{s} applies its brakes at time t=0, its velocity (in \textrm{m}/\textrm{s}) decreasing according to the formula v(t) = 30 - 10t. How far does the car go before it stops?

hint.p: When does the car stop? What is the relation between velocity and distance travelled?

solution.p:
The car stops when v(t)=30-10t=0, which occurs at time t = 3. The distance covered up to that time is
\int_0^3 v(t)\,\dee{t} = (30t - 5t^2)\Big|_{0}^{3} = (90-45)-0 = 45\,\textrm{m}.

statement.p: Compute f'(x) where f(x)= \displaystyle\int_0^{2x-x^2}\log\big(1+e^t\big)\,\dee{t}. Does f(x) have an absolute maximum? Explain.

hint.p: See Example . For the absolute maximum part of the question, study the sign of f'(x).

answer.p: f'(x)=(2-2x)\log\big(1+e^{2x-x^2}\big) and f(x) achieves its absolute maximum at x=1, because f(x) is increasing for x \lt 1 and decreasing for x \gt 1.

solution.p:
Define g(x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x\log\big(1+e^t\big)\,\dee{t}. By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, g'(x) = \log\big(1+e^x\big). But f(x)=g(2x-x^2), so by the chain rule,
f'(x)=g'(2x-x^2)\cdot \diff{}{x}\{2x-x^2\} =(2-2x)\cdot\log\big(1+e^{2x-x^2}\big)
Observe that e^{2x-x^2} \gt 0 for all x so that 1+e^{2x-x^2} \gt 1 for all x and \log\big(1+e^{2x-x^2}\big) \gt 0 for all x. Since 2-2x is positive for x \lt 1 and negative for x \gt 1, f'(x) is also positive for x \lt 1 and negative for x \gt 1. That is, f(x) is increasing for x \lt 1 and decreasing for x \gt 1. So f(x) achieves its absolute maximum at x=1.

statement.p: Find the minimum value of \displaystyle\int_0^{x^2-2x}\frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^4}. Express your answer as an integral.

hint.p: See Example . For the minimum value part of the question, study the sign of f'(x).

answer.p: The minimum is \int_0^{-1} \frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^4}. As x runs from -\infty to \infty, the function f(x)= \int_0^{x^2-2x}\frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^4} decreases until x reaches 1 and then increases all x \gt 1. So the minimum is achieved for x=1. At x=1, x^2-2x=-1.

solution.p: Let f(x)=\int_0^{x^2-2x}\frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^4} and g(x)= \int_0^{x}\frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^4}. Then g'(x)=\frac{1}{1+x^4} and, since f(x)=g(x^2-2x), f'(x)=(2x-2)g'(x^2-2x)=2\frac{x-1}{1+(x^2-2x)^4}. This is zero for x=1, negative for x \lt 1 and positive for x \gt 1. Thus as x runs from -\infty to \infty, f(x) decreases until x reaches 1 and then increases all x \gt 1. So the minimum of f(x) is achieved for x=1. At x=1, x^2-2x=-1 and f(1)=\int_0^{-1}\frac{\dee{t}}{1+t^4}.

statement.p: Define the function F(x)=\displaystyle\int_0^{x^2}\sin(\sqrt{t})\,\dee{t} on the interval 0 \lt x \lt 4. On this interval, where does F(x) have a maximum?

hint.p: See Example . For the maximum part of the question, study the sign of F'(x).

answer.p: F achieves its maximum value at x=\pi.

solution.p: Define G(x)=\displaystyle\int_0^x\sin(\sqrt{t})\,\dee{t}. By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, G'(x)=\sin(\sqrt{x}). Since F(x)=G(x^2), and since x \gt 0, we have F'(x)=2xG'(x^2)=2x\sin |x|=2x\sin x. Thus F increases as x runs from to 0 to \pi (since F'(x) \gt 0 there) and decreases as x runs from \pi to 4 (since F'(x) \lt 0 there). Thus F achieves its maximum value at x=\pi.

statement.p: Evaluate \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}\dfrac{\pi}{n}\displaystyle\sum\limits_{j=1}^n \sin\left(\frac{j\pi}{n}\right) by interpreting it as a limit of Riemann sums.

hint.p: Review the definition of the definite integral and in particular Definitions and .

solution.p:
The given sum is of the form
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{j=1}^n \frac{\pi}{n}\sin\Big(\frac{j\pi}{n}\Big) =\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{j=1}^n f(x_j^*)\De x
with \De x=\frac{\pi}{n}, x_j^*=\frac{j\pi}{n} and f(x)=\sin(x). Since x_0^*=0 and x_n^*=\pi, the right hand side is the definition (using the right Riemann sum) of
\int_0^\pi f(x)\,\dee{x}=\int_0^\pi \sin(x)\,\dee{x} =\left[-\cos(x)\right]_0^\pi=2
where we evaluate the definite integral using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 2.

hint.p: Review the definition of the definite integral and in particular Definitions and .

solution.p:
The given sum is of the form
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^n \frac{1}{1+\frac{j}{n}} =\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{j=1}^n f(x_j)\De x
with \De x=\frac{1}{n}, x_j=\frac{j}{n} and f(x)=\frac{1}{1+x}. The right hand side is the definition (using the right Riemann sum) of
\int_0^1 f(x)\,\dee{x}=\int_0^1 \frac{1}{1+x}\,\dee{x} =\log|1+x|\Big|_0^1 =\log 2

statement.p: Below is the graph of y=f(t), -5 \leq t \leq 5. Define F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{0}^x f(t)\dee{t} for any x in [-5,5]. Sketch F(x).

hint.p: Carefully check the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus: as written, it only applies directly to F(x) when x\ge0.
Is F(x) even or odd?

answer.p: In the sketch below, open dots denote inflection points, and closed dots denote extrema.

li.p: \mathbf{F(x),\,x \ge 0}: We learned quite a lot last semester about curve sketching. We can use those techniques here. We have to be quite careful about the sign of x, though. We can only directly apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1 (as it's written in your text) when x\ge 0. So first, let's graph the right-hand portion. Notice f(x) has even symmetry--so, if we know one half of F(x), we should be able to figure out the other half with relative ease.

ul.li: F(0)=\displaystyle\int_0^0 f(t)\dee{t}=0 (so, F(x) passes through the origin)

li.p: Using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, F'(x) \gt 0 when 0 \lt x \lt 1 and when 3 \lt x \lt 5; F'(x) \lt 0 when 1 \lt x \lt 3. So, F(x) is decreasing from 1 to 3, and increasing from 0 to 1 and also from 3 to 5. That gives us a skeleton to work with.

We get the relative sizes of the maxes and mins by eyeballing the area under y=f(t). The first lobe (from x=0 to x=1 has a small positive area, so F(1) is a small positive number. The next lobe (from x=1 to x=3) has a larger absolute area than the first, so F(3) is negative. Indeed, the second lobe seems to have more than twice the area of the first, so |F(3)| should be larger than F(1). The third lobe is larger still, and even after subtracting the area of the second lobe it looks much larger than the first or second lobe, so |F(3)| \lt F(5).

We can use F''(x) to get the concavity of F(x). Note F''(x)=f'(x). We observe f(x) is decreasing on (roughly) (0,2.5) and (4,5), so F(x) is concave down on those intervals. Further, f(x) is increasing on (roughly) (2.5,4), so F(x) is concave up there, and has inflection points at about x=2.5 and x=4.
In the sketch above, closed dots are extrema, and open dots are inflection points.

statement.p:
Define f(x)=x^3\displaystyle\int_{0}^{x^3+1} e^{t^3} \dee{t}.
Find a formula for the derivative f'(x). (Your formula may include an integral sign.)
Find the equation of the tangent line to the graph of y=f(x) at x=-1.

hint.p: In general, the equation of the tangent line to the graph of y=f(x) at x=a is y=f(a) + f'(a)\,(x-a).

solution.p:
(b) In general, the equation of the tangent line to the graph of y=f(x) at x=a is
y=f(a) + f'(a)\,(x-a)
Substituting in the given f(x) and a=-1:
f(a)=f(-1)&=(-1)^3\int_0^0 e^{t^3}\dee{t}=0
f'(a)=f'(-1)&=3(-1)^2\int_{0}^{0}e^{t^3}\dee{t} + 3(-1)^5e^{0}
&=0-3=-3
(x-a)=x-(-1)&=x+1
So, the equation of the tangent line is y = -3(x+1)\ .

statement.p:
Two students calculate \int f(x)\dee{x} for some function f(x).
Student A calculates \int f(x)\dee{x} = \tan^2 x + x + C
Student B calculates \int f(x)\dee{x} = \sec^2 x + x + C
It is a fact that \diff{}{x}\{\tan^2 x\} = f(x)-1
Who ended up with the correct answer?

hint.p: Recall \tan^2x+1=\sec^2 x.

solution.p: Recall that +C means that we can add any constant to the function. Since \tan^2 x = \sec^2 x - 1, Students A and B have equivalent answers: they only differ by a constant.

So, if one is right, both are right; if one is wrong, both are wrong. We check Student A's work:
\diff{}{x}\{\tan^2 x + x + C\}=\diff{}{x}\{\tan^2 x\} +1 + 0 = f(x)-1+1=f(x)
So, Student A's answer is indeed an anditerivative of f(x). Therefore, both students ended up with the correct answer.
Remark: it is a frequent occurrence that equivalent answers might look quite different. As you are comparing your work to others', this is a good thing to keep in mind!

statement.p:
Let F(x)=\displaystyle\int_0^x x^3 \sin(t)\dee{t}.
Evaluate F(3).
What is F'(x)?

hint.p: Since the integration is with respect to t, the x^3 term can be moved outside the integral.

ol.label: a

solution.p: Remark: Since x and t play different roles in our problem, it's crucial that they have different names. This is one reason why we should avoid the common mistake of writing \int_a^x f(x)\dee{x} when we mean \int_a^x f(t)\dee{t}.

statement.p: Let f(x) be an even function, defined everywhere, and let F(x) be an antiderivative of f(x). Is F(x) even, odd, or not necessarily either one? (You may use your answer from Section, Question. )

hint.p: Remember that antiderivatives may have a constant term.

answer.p: If f(x)=0 for all x, then F(x) is even and possibly also odd.
If f(x) \neq 0 for some x, then F(x) is not even. It might be odd, and it might be neither even nor odd.
(Perhaps surprisingly, every antiderivative of an odd function is even.)

solution.p: If F(x) is even, then f(x) is odd (by the result of Question in Section). So, F(x) can only be even if f(x) is both even and odd. By the result in Question, Section, this means F(x) is only even if f(x)=0 for all x. Note if f(x)=0, then F(x) is a constant function. So, it is certainly even, and it might be odd as well if F(x)=f(x)=0.

Therefore, if f(x) \neq 0 for some x, then F(x) is not even. It could be odd, or it could be neither even nor odd. We can come up with examples of both types: if f(x)=1, then F(x)=x is an odd antiderivative, and F(x)=x+1 is an antiderivative that is neither even nor odd.

Interestingly, the antiderivative of an odd function is always even. The proof is a little beyond what we might ask you, but is given below for completeness. The proof goes like this: First, we'll show that if g(x) is odd, then there is some antiderivative of g(x) that is even. Then, we'll show that every antiderivative of g(x) is even.

So, suppose g(x) is odd and define G(x)=\displaystyle\int_0^x g(t)\dee{t}. By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, G'(x)=g(x), so G(x) is an antiderivative of g(x). Since g(x) is odd, for any x\ge 0, the net signed area under the curve along [0,x] is the negative of the net signed area under the curve along [-x,0]. So,
\int_0^x g(t)\dee{}t &= - \int_{-x}^0 g(t)\dee{t}&\quad(\mbox{See Example })
&=\int_0^{-x} g(t)\dee{t}
By the definition of G(x), G(x)&=G(-x)
That is, G(x) is even. We've shown that there exists some antiderivative of g(x) that is even; it remains to show that all of them are even.

Recall that every antiderivative of g(x) differs from G(x) by some constant. So, any antiderivative of g(x) can be written as G(x)+C, and G(-x)+C = G(x)+C. So, every antiderivative of an odd function is even.
